Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she opens her laptop to find an email from HR titled "Performance Review." She clicks it open and reads, "We regret to inform you..." Her stomach drops as she realizes the project she'd poured herself into for months has been reassigned. Tears well up in her eyes, blurring the screen. The silence feels heavy, suffocating. She reaches out to pet her cat, seeking comfort, but he's not there. He passed away last week.

They don't want to let go of someone who makes people happy. If only I could make the boss happy, everything would change. I'll try harder next time, even though we all know it won't work. There's no point anymore. It's always going to end like this. I'm doomed. Everyone else gets praised for their work, while I'm constantly criticized. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A chef, late 40s, stands over her prep counter at home, knife poised above an unblemished onion. Her husband enters the kitchen, briefcase in hand, and says casually, "I thought we could try that new restaurant downtown tonight." She freezes, knuckles turning white around the handle. "But... it's Friday," she manages to say, voice tight. "And I've got the hollandaise sauce ready for tomorrow's brunch." Her breath hitches as she forces a smile, but her eyes dart nervously between the onion and her husband's expectant gaze.
Generated Assessment: "I don't think this is going well. It's like he thinks everything is fine just because he said something about trying a new place, like if you had nothing planned, you'd always want to go out? He doesn't get how much work goes into making things perfect - does he know how hard I worked on the menu this week? And now he wants to go somewhere else? Are they even open yet?" She glances back at the onion, her mind racing with worst-case scenarios. The kitchen feels smaller than usual, and every sound echoes louder. "Maybe I'll just start cleaning up here instead..." But the thought of leaving the house sends her spiraling. "No way - I'm done with cooking today." Her husband looks puzzled by her sudden change of plans, but she can't bring herself to explain. Instead, she keeps her focus on the onion, which now seems ominous. What if she cuts herself? Or worse, what if he leaves her? The tension builds, and she starts to feel trapped, as if her husband's casual suggestion has unleashed a chain reaction of disaster. She tries to shake off the feeling, telling herself it's just anxiety from a long day of cooking, but deep down, she knows it's more than that. This isn't just about food; it's about control, comfort, and the fear of losing her identity as a cook. Maybe she's just tired, but somehow, her mind is convinced that this is all connected

Triggering Event: She arrived at the newspaper office, a place she'd once called her second home. Now, it was just another reminder of his absence. Her colleagues greeted her with concerned smiles, whispering about the latest scandal that had erupted overnight. She scanned the room, looking for her usual desk, but found it occupied by an eager intern. Helplessness washed over her as she realized there was no place left for her, no space to call her own anymore.

What if we were still together? Would things have worked out? Would I be happy again? Or would I just feel stuck? I can't even bear to look at myself in the mirror. My life has fallen apart. What if this wasn't meant to happen? Why did I let him go? He said he needed space, but deep down, I knew he didn't want to leave. Maybe if I'd been more patient, listened better, or been more understanding, none of this would have happened. But why am I thinking like this? What if I'm just making excuses for my failure? Am I really that weak? Can I even trust myself? Do I deserve happiness anyway? I feel so alone, yet everyone else seems fine. They're moving forward, while I'm stuck in the past, wondering what could've been. If only I had been stronger, braver, or wiser... What if I'd never met him? Would I still be here? Would I still exist? Is it worth it? Should I give up now? Does anyone care? Maybe I'm just deluding myself, imagining a reality where things made sense. But then why does it feel so real? Maybe I should stop dwelling on the past. What if I try to move on? What if

Triggering Event: A middle-aged scientist, his eyes weary from hours of poring over data, glances at his clock. It's 7 PM. He'd asked his graduate student to have the lab reports ready by now, but the office is still empty. He feels a familiar irritation rise within him; another evening ruined by someone else's negligence.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, seriously? I'm sitting here at 7 PM, waiting for some papers that are supposed to be done by now, and there's no sign of them. I swear, it's like they're trying to make me look bad. The way I see it, they either don't care about deadlines or they just want to watch me work myself into a frenzy so I can fail our project. I mean, what's wrong with these people? Can't they even keep track of time? It's not like we're asking for perfection. We've been working on this for months, and suddenly, now, it's too much to handle? And then there's the fact that I know one of them has been out late all day, possibly partying, and yet... nothing. No excuse, no apology, just an endless cycle of incompetence. I feel like I'm stuck in some kind of cruel joke, where everyone's playing against each other, and nobody cares about results. Does she think we're buddies now because they were hanging out? That's so fucked up. She knows nothing about us, nothing about our history. Why are people doing this shit? It makes me sick. How can anyone act like this? What am I missing? Maybe if I took a closer look, I could understand why...but no, I won't waste my time trying to figure out something I don’t need to know. I already feel stupid enough for letting him take my spot, but now I have to deal with this too? What a nightmare. I wish someone would tell me how to handle this situation, but nobody ever listens when I ask. Now I’m stuck dealing with this bullshit by myself. Everyone else gets away with these things while I get treated like shit. It’s always like this—no one cares how much I suffer, but they'll jump right into action if they see someone else getting hurt. This is such a pain; I just want to scream. Triggering Event: Her partner, unaware of her deadline, suggested they go out for dinner with friends, expecting her to drop everything. She felt the resentment bubble up as she looked at the stack of unpublished articles and unanswered emails.
Generated Assessment: FUCK THIS Bitches are so fucking lucky. They get to be free and live life like it's a vacation while I'm stuck here working my ass off to pay bills. It makes me so angry that I can't even tell if it's rage or sadness anymore. The irony is that they're probably enjoying themselves right now because they have nothing to worry about, but I'm still stuck in this miserable cycle of work and stress. Why does it always have to be them? They don't care about deadlines; they just want to hang out and eat. Meanwhile, I'm drowning in responsibilities, and I've been waiting for what feels like an eternity for them to understand how much pressure I'm under. It's just not fair. I feel like I'm constantly fighting against time and expectations, while they get to relax and enjoy life. This is such bullshit. Why does it always have to be this way?

Triggering Event: He woke before dawn, the house eerily silent save for the ticking of his late wife's antique clock. His hands, gnarled by age and arthritis, struggled with the zipper of his worn uniform. The store wouldn't open for hours, but routine was all he had left. As he stepped out into the chill morning, a lone magpie swooped low, its harsh caw echoing his empty heart. Another day alone, another shift in this endless parade of emptiness.
Generated Assessment: He's such an old bastard, always grumbling about how hard life is now that his wife passed away. I've heard him say it so many times—'Life sucks after you lose your partner,' he'll say with a snort. It's like he thinks being alone makes everything harder than it already was. But what does he know? He's just been through hell himself. I remember when they were first married, they'd cuddle up together at night, holding hands and talking about their dreams. Now, it's just him lying awake, counting down until the sun rises again. It's so unfair. Everyone says, "Just get over it," like it's easy to forget someone who's been there for 40 years. He doesn't want to talk about it; he just wants to go back to work. At least then he can pretend nothing has changed. But every time we have dinner together, he breaks down, and I'm just...there. Trying to comfort him while my mind screams, _Why can't you just move on?!_ Why does it have to be so hard? Every time I try to reach out, he pushes me away. Like, why would he ever open up? Maybe if I could understand what really goes on behind those tears, I'd figure out how to help him heal. But no, he just keeps telling me, "You don't know shit." That's fair, I guess. Triggering Event: While plating the signature dish for tonight's special, he noticed a slight imperfection in the sauce, reminiscent of his wife's careless remark this morning about his "obsessive perfectionism." Bitterness welled up as he scraped off the offending smear, ruining hours of work.
Generated Assessment: You're so uptight about everything! It was just an accident, but you're acting like it's personal. You need to relax! He's really sensitive about his cooking. He thinks everyone can see how much effort goes into each dish, even if it doesn't turn out perfectly. That's why he gets so upset when things don't meet his standards. It's not about being perfect; it's about putting love and care into what he does. Maybe instead of beating yourself up over a small mistake, you could focus on enjoying the process? And remember, your wife said she loves your cooking, even with imperfections. She didn't mean to make you feel like you're failing—she probably just wants you to have fun with it too! It's okay if dishes aren’t flawless; maybe try making something simpler next time? Just chill out and stop taking it so seriously. He's trying to be better, but you always find fault in everything. Stop worrying so much and let him learn at his own pace. If you were so worried about perfection all the time, you wouldn’t have made such a mess in the kitchen earlier today. You’re stressing over nothing, and it’s driving him crazy because he knows you’re like that. Relax, take a deep breath, and let him enjoy the process. The most important thing is spending quality time together, not being perfect chefs. Let go of your expectations and give him some space to breathe.

Triggering Event: At 7 PM, after a day of teaching unruly students, he found the kitchen sink filled with dirty dishes - his ex-wife's parting 'gift' before leaving him for their divorce lawyer. His frustration boiled over as he forcefully plunged his hands into the cold, greasy water.
